Some rough categories: * Viral copyleft: - GPL
* Trademark/reputation-protecting licenses: - Knuth's TeX license (see http://lists.debian.org/debian-legal/2002/08/msg00054.html) - Perl's Artistic License
* Do whatever you want, maybe give us credit: - BSD - Apache - X - what else?

Free software licenses fall into three basic categories:
Those designed to ensure the software can only be used in other free programs.
Those designed to protect the credit and reputation of the author(s) of the software.
Those designed to allow as wide and unlimited distribution of the software as possible, while still retaining copyright for the original authors.
Note that some licenses combine functions (1) and (2), but they seem to be rarely used.
The most popular type (1) license is the GNU General Public License, or GPL (see ). The GPL's most controversial attribute is that any work which uses GPL'd code must also be released under the GPL. If all the free software in the world were under the GPL, this would merely mean that GPL'd code could be shared among free programs, but not used in proprietary programs.
However, as there are other free licenses besides the GPL, the GPL can sometimes prevent (or at least discourage) code-swapping even between two free programs. From the point of view of the Free Software Foundation, these second-order consequences are desirable. The GPL not only keeps your software free, but effectively makes your software an agent in pushing other software to enforce freedom as well.
Whether it's the right license for your project depends on your goals. If you want absolutely the widest possible use of the software, and don't mind its being incorporated into proprietary programs, the GPL is not a good choice. If you mainly intend the project
The GPL cannot be categorized as innately business-friendly or business-unfriendly. fooo
Depending on your goals, and how you want your program to be used, this may or may not be what you want.
Perhaps surprisingly, the GPL can make better business sense than some other licenses, because it prevents competitors from using the software in a proprietary value-add.
(Competitors often won't mind credit clauses.)
In general, using the GPL may put off some developers; whereas a non-GPL free license will not put off any. Nevertheless, I sometimes use the GPL for personal programs
